entry.title: Recently Consumed Delicious Anime and Manga
entry.content:
I’ve been getting really into anime and manga again, which happens occasionally. The last time this happened was with Sword Art Online, an anime I loved until the second season, which led the story down into an incestuous love triangle and a hideous, totally unncessary sexual assault scene.

Here’s an overview of some anime/manga I’ve found recently.

Anime: Kuragehime / 海月姫 / Princess Jellyfish

(via)

Amamizukan is an apartment complex where no boys are allowed. Tsukimi, a girl who adores jellyfish, lives there happily with her friends who all have nerdy obsessions of their own. Their peaceful lives gradually start to change when a beautiful woman helps Tsukimi out of a pinch. She stays overnight at the apartments—but it turns out "she" is really a "he". (via)

Status: Complete. Genre: Jousei/Romance/Comedy.

H has been heavily encouraging me to watch this series for years and I finally set aside time for it after finding it on Netflix!

Reasons why you should watch it:

  • It's legitimately hilarious. Even A, who generally despises anime, enjoyed it. This is really saying something.
  • There are varied female characters! With varied appearances and varied interests!
  • Kuranosuke's crossdressing/femme presentation isn't used by the main cast as something to belittle him.
  • Surprisingly, it's the only story I've ever consumed where I didn't really mind the love triangle and felt like I was rooting for both sides of it.

Unfortunately:

  • The ending is pretty sudden.

Manga: Kuragehime / 海月姫 / Princess Jellyfish, HIGASHIMURA Akiko

(via)

Kuragehime follows Tsukimi Kurashita, an 18-year-old who moved from Kagoshima to Tokyo to become an illustrator. Tsukimi is a jellyfish otaku who comes to live in a shared bath and toilet, women-only apartment, Amamizukan. Other tenants include fujoshi, NEETs and others who consider fashion their natural enemy, calling themselves "Amars". One day, Tsukimi meets a fashionable and beautiful girl, Kuranosuke Koibuchi, who saves a jellyfish that is about to die at a pet shop. She later discovers that Kuranosuke is merely cross-dressing in order to evade inheritance of his father's occupation as a politician. (via)

Status: Ongoing. Genre: Jousei/Romance/Comedy.

Being dissatisfied with the anime’s ending, I chased up the manga.

Reasons why you should read it:

  • Though the rendering of events isn't as funny as in the anime, it's still pretty cute.
  • (spoilers) The manga doesn't make it look as if Shuu is falling in love with the woman sexually blackmailing him, which is good.
  • The author also has short manga detailing events in her own life, and they're *such funny wow*.

Manga: Dengeki Daisy / 電撃デイジー, MOTOMI Kyousuke

(via)

After orphan Teru Kurebayashi loses her beloved older brother, she finds solace in the messages she exchanges with Daisy, an enigmatic figure who can only be reached through the cell phone her brother left her. Meanwhile, Teru meets and forms a strange friendship with mysterious Tasuku Kurosaki, her school's janitor. For some reason, Kurosaki always seems to be around whenever Teru needs help which leads Teru to wonder: Could Daisy be a lot closer than she thinks?

As the mystery of Daisy unfolds, Teru also discovers that there may have been a lot more to the life and death of her brother than she ever dreamed...and that the man she thought was her friend just might have all the answers.(via)

Status: Ongoing. Genre: Shoujo/Romance/Comedy.

This was recommended to me by Tumblr friends.

Reasons why you should read it:

  • It's so cute wow. If you need a heavy dose of thick, syrupy shoujo, this is it. This is it.
  • Teru The Protagonist is an awesome female lead, and though there are some "damsel" moments, she mostly has impressive/fun moments where she saves herself and the entire day just when the author leads you to expect the opposite. (Wow such subversive!)
  • Teru also has friendships with other girls, both of whom she confides in and supports throughout the series.
  • There's a girl who could totally be slut-shamed, and she isn't.
  • This series is the first I've seen to depict a relationship growing significantly through communicating with each other digitally, which is pretty tight.
  • The main male lead is a HACKER! :'D

Unfortunately:

  • It's really cheesy. Really cheesy. When you're not getting cavities, you're drowning in cheese. Though really, depending on your mood, this is kind of a plus.

Manga: Kamisama Hajimemashia | 神様はじめました / Kamisama Kiss, SUZUKI Julietta

(via)

Momozono Nanami’s dad, a man with a penchant for gambling, disappeared after accumulating a huge amount of debt. Thus, she was chased out of her house by the debt collectors. When she met a timid guy being chased by a dog, he told her that he’d give her his house. She believed his persuasive talk, but when she went to his house… it turned out to be a shrine. Moreover, a guy with fox ears appeared, which made Nanami even more confused. What will become of homeless and confused Nanami? (via)

Status: Ongoing. Genre: Shoujo/Supernatural/Romance/Comedy.

I’ve actually been reading this for a while, but it’s worth another shout-out because I’ve been re-reading it and it’s one of my favorite series to date, right up there with Full Metal Panic!.

Reasons why you should read it:

  • The supernatural premise is fun, and the majority of the characters have a lot of charm. (The only one I can't totally get behind is Mizuki, mostly because he seems the most unnecessary to the plot.)
  • Nanami The Protagonist gets stuff done! Woo!
  • Tomoe is a well-developed male lead. He has bangs, a dark past, animal ears, cooking skills — everything you could ever possibly desire on this imperfect earth.
  • I really love Suzuki-sensei's unconventional-looking art style.
  • *Time paradox!*

Unfortunately:

  • Recent chapters (specifically, 92 and 107) have had some uncomfortable dubcon scenes. Ultimately Suzuki-sensei has handled these scenes in an alright way...but I wish she'd have her characters call out and condemn the problematic aspects head-on.
  • The story recently has also been slowing down and felt uncomfortably off-pace, though I'm not giving up on it just yet.

Anime: Kamisama Hajimemashita / 神様はじめました / Kamisama Kiss

(via)

After her father having run away due to gambling debts, and being evicted from her apartment, Nanami meets Mikage, a strange man who is afraid of dogs. Nanami "saves" Mikage from a dog and tells him her story. He gives Nanami his house as a thank you for saving him. Nanami accepts the offer, due to having nowhere else to go. Mikage draws her up a map showing her where to go. Upon arriving, she finds that it is a rundown shrine. Nanami is then almost killed by Tomoe, who was expecting Mikage to finally return after his 20 year absence. She is then greeted by both Onikiri and Kotetsu, as the new land god of the shrine. Unable to accept Nanami as the new land god, Tomoe mocks her then leaves the shrine, which, without Tomoe's power transforms back into a run-down state. Not wanting to rob Tomoe of his home and realizing that her powers as a god are too weak anyway Nanami leaves, but eventually is brought back by Tomoe after she seals a contract with him, making him her familiar. (via)

Status: Complete. Genre: Shoujo/Supernatural/Romance/Comedy.

Reasons why you should watch it:

  • Nanami's voice actress is perfectly casted. Perfectly.
  • If you enjoyed the manga, you'd probably also enjoy seeing some of the scenes animated?

Unfortunately:

  • Nanami has less agency in the anime, and I don't Recent chapters (specifically, 92 and 107) have had some uncomfortable dubcon scenes. Ultimately Suzuki-sensei has handled these scenes in an alright way...but I wish she'd have her characters call out and condemn the problematic aspects head-on.
  • The story recently has also been slowing down and felt uncomfortably off-pace, though I'm not giving up on it just yet.

Anime: Free! Iwatobi Swim Club

(via)

Four boys named Haruka, Makoto, Nagisa and Rin all participated in a swimming tournament shortly before graduating elementary school and later parted ways. Years later, they reunite when Rin challenges Haruka to a race and wins. Not wanting to be defeated so easily, Haruka gathers Makoto and Nagisa and a new recruit named Rei to form the Iwatobi High School Swimming Club. (via)

Status: Complete. Genre: Comedy/Sports…?

How could I not watch this? After all, it’s the series that Tumblr made.

Reasons why you should watch it:

  • The animation is pretty. I even read on Tumblr that the actual swimming movements were pretty accurate. Neat.

Unfortunately:

  • The story is just alright.
  • Queer-baiting (used extensively here) is boring.

Anime: Kyoukai no Kanata / 境界の彼方 / Beyond the Boundary

(via)

Akihito Kanbara is a high school sophomore in the literature club who believes himself to be a "Meganest", and although he appears to be human, he is actually half Yōmu, which makes him invulnerable to wounds, due to the fact that he can heal so quickly, and also immortal. One day, Akihito meets freshman Mirai Kuriyama when it appears as if she is about to attempt suicide by jumping off of the school rooftop. Mirai is isolated because of her ability to manipulate blood, which is considered heresy even among other members of the underworld, so she is shunned. Soon after Akihito saves Mirai, disturbing events begin to arise. (via)

Status: Complete. Genre: Action/Romance/Comedy/Fantasy.

I was lured into watching this anime because of the gorgeous animation and my instant affinity for the main character, who has red glasses not totally unlike my own. Also, “meganest” in the description above stands for the fact that Akihito is really into women who wear glasses.

Reasons why you should watch it:

  • Like Free!, also by Kyoto Animation, the animation (especially with the fight scenes) is gorgeous.
  • If, like me, you are a sucker for the forbidden romance between a "demon-type person" and "demon-slayer-type person" — well, here it is.
  • I love the ending song, which is Stereo Dive Foundation's Daisy.

Unfortunately:

  • The moeblob is strong with this one.
  • The ending was rushed and I...still don't really get what happened.
  • The two main male characters are overly obsesssed with their fetishes. It's annoying at least and disturbing at worst, especially since the girl characters they're focusing their fetishes on are clearly uncomfortable.
  • To be honest, this series as a whole fell flat for me, but the eyecandy was quite filling.

entry.title: Wolf Children Ame and Yuki
entry.content:
(source)

(spoilers)

I watched Wolf Children: Ame and Yuki the other day and was taken aback at how I pretty much had tears flowing continuously down my face, starting from the dam scene until the end of the movie . (What is it like to love someone and then see their body thrown into the back of a garbage truck? Oh God)

It’s a story that I would be surprised to find in the US, because despite the fact that the title alludes to the wolf-shapeshifting children, the story is just as much about their mother, Hana, and her struggles to raise the children, aided only by her dead partner’s dwindling savings. She learns about natural birth to avoid going to hospitals; she fights off health inspectors; at some point her daughter accidentally ingests detergent and there’s an amusing scene of her rushing off into the night and then glancing desperately back and forth between a children’s hospital and a pet clinic.

Though Hana misses her partner, at no point does she ever really find a replacement for him, or need another man at all. Even when she moves into the countryside, she receives assistance from the entire community there (though there is vaguely tsundere old man involved). Though her partner was a wolfman and is the reason why her children are also partially wolves, he just isn’t a part of the equation after he leaves. It sounds simple, but it’s such a relief that there are stories out there about women persevering, doing their own thing against all odds, and ultimately finding a place where they (and their children) can just be themselves.

It’s also just a relief to see a woman who isn’t vilified for being a single mother, who isn’t ultimately viewed as lesser and unwhole for her lack of a man, who loses him and continues to move on with her life. Despite what much media would have you believe, without men, women keep existing and struggling towards their own goals.

It's true that Hana’s motivations center almost entirely on the health of her children, which on its own isn’t terribly stereotype-breaking, but I appreciated how Hana didn’t lose her personality to become a faceless machine of a mother figure, a character wholly defined by her offspring’s emotions. Her bright attitude could have been unbelievable, but was acceptable to me because it is something established as a defining trait: "Even at my father’s funeral I laughed." And even so, it doesn’t mean she’s perfect: she often admits her ignorance (and remedies it thoroughly researching all her problems), she cries, she bandages her fingers, she panics, and rubs her back when it aches. You also get a glimpse of Hana's life as it was before motherhood, and a little "after," once her children have embarked

And now that all of that is said — though Wolf Children impressed me with its focus on Hana as a single mother, after talking about this movie with Heather, I learned that the "virtuous mother" is actually a trope not uncommon in Eastern narratives. I haven't noticed it much, but will definitely be keeping an eye on it from now on.

entry.title: Sword Art Online: So Pretty
entry.content:
So I found a gifset of Sword Art Online on Tumblr and decided that I wanted to watch it, because the art is pretty and also because the characters looked familiar, probably because Sword Art Online is one of the light novels I bought (and subsequently lost) some time ago.

Well, no matter!

Sword Art Online (SAO) details the adventures of Kirito, who is one of ten thousand players trapped in the newly-released "virtual reality" MMORPG of the same name. The creator of SAO, who turns out to be some kind of eccentric psychopath, removes the "Log Out" button on the first day of open play and announces that everyone will have to reach and defeat Floor 100 in order to return back to the Real World. In the meantime, if you die in the game, you die in real life.

I was excited because Kirito has bangs (my favorite ridiculous anime hair affectation) and spends the opening looking Dark and Tormented (my favorite ridiculous anime stereotype). Additionally, the "main" female character, Asuna, appears in the opening running around and doing things.

go, asuna, go! clear that low bar of agency!

[spoilers ahead]

Inevitably this first season was full of the same old tired female character stereotypes/storylines/actions, including but not limited to:

  • female characters that basically act as pretty receptacles and mirrors for Kirito's feelings, for example:
    • Silica, Dragon Tamer Girl: who appeared for one episode to be Kirito's "little sister," with bonus panicked upskirts
    • Lisbeth, Smith Girl: who appeared for one episode to be a love interest that is irrelevant after the one episode
  • male characters not caring that female characters don't like them or want to be near them, for example:
    • That one guy refuses to stop being Asuna's escort, and says he'll only leave her alone if Kirito wins against him a duel (what)
    • The leader of Asuna's guild, who, when Asuna tells him she wants to leave the guild, says she can only leave if Kirito wins against him in a duel (what)
  • There's also a sub-plot that involves a woman who is murdered by her husband because, in the life-threatening situation of Sword Art Online, she stopped being "cute and obedient" and became instead a "lively and active" guild leader...what? It's obvious that this particular guy character is horrible, but I guess I'm bewildered by this story, which seemed to come out of nowhere, and didn't really serve to teach any characters about anything. Maybe if at the end Kirito had thought something like, Wow, this really makes me appreciate Asuna's fighting skill more...?

The things that I did enjoy about this anime were the little game-related details, which take on a "private joke" feeling that I think was delightful and not uncomfortably blatant with fanfare and winking ("Hey! That was a game reference! Get it? Eh? Ehhhh?"). Characters gossip about other characters who have legendary status because their "HP bar has never fallen to yellow." At some point Kirito hits a wall in anger and the wall flashes with a notification -- IMMORTAL OBJECT -- indicating that it's inanimate and indestructible  Best part: this little moment turns out to have plot significance later. Whoa! I really appreciate the meaningful subtlety.

It's also fun to view what happens to characters as they become trapped in the digital world, though I wish it were explored more, perhaps in lieu of unnecessary female character fanservice. Some people commit suicide; some dedicate themselves to fighting on "the front lines" to free everyone; some people become merchants and smiths to support the fighters. One old man, thinking that he'd never get his real-life job back anyway, decides that he'll perfect in-game fishing.

Inevitably Kirito and Asuna fall into a relationship, an unexpectedly intense and serious romance that involves them getting married (in-game) and living together in a cabin in the woods (on the game's Floor 22) and eventually meeting a girl that they "adopt" as their daughter (who later turns out to be a game process AI). Something that's refreshing about their relationship is the trust they have in each other -- Kirito occasionally hangs behind while Asuna fights, and at one point just smiles when someone tries to warn him to get his wife out of the way of a giant attacking fish. Though they were rarer than the opposite, I appreciated the parts where Kirito gave Asuna a place to stand on her own and defend and be appreciated for her actions and thoughts and talents, which weren't all Kirito-centered (for example, her experimentation with cooking and seeing which mixture of in-game loots and essences could make real-world flavors like soy sauce).

Given the intensity of their dedication to each other (Kirito declares to Asuna that his entire self belongs to her; Asuna says that if Kirito dies, she'll commit suicide), it's uncomfortable and bewildering why the second season of SAO, which is still on-going, keeps pushing this love triangle forward between Kirito and his sister-who-is-actually-his-cousin. I mean, this isn't going to pan out, right? Is this just an excuse to keep having unrequited romantic (slash incestuous and forbidden) tension in the show to keep people watching? Is devoted love so boring? After all that the two characters have been through together, and after the show gives you so much reason to invest in the semi-doomed lovebank of Kirito/Asuna, it's hard to see this extra, new girl as anything but annoying fan service.

Something else a little depressing is the impending descent of Asuna into a caged bird that doesn't do much but stare forlornly into space whenever her captor, a despised fiancé in a real-world arranged marriage who is keeping her unconscious and trapped in a new MMORPG, comes to threaten her warmly with sexual assault or erasure of her memories. In the most recent episode, Asuna sneakily watched him unlock the door to her cage, which made me assume hopefully that she would try to escape on her own. Unfortunately, she just collapsed on her knees and cried, "Save me, Kirito!"

It's not that I blame her for her circumstances or think that she could fight her way out of it if she wanted...I just don't want her to become a full-on damsel in distress. :(

low bar of agency: not cleared (source)

Having met the end of the anime that's presently out, I've been devouring the light novels, where fanservice-y upskirts are not as prominent and where Asuna is more of an active character during the "fairy" arc, escaping and fighting and doing what she can. As a series the whole thing is really fun to watch -- it's beautiful, and really stretches, embroiders, and uses its theme of video game worlds and realities.

entry.title: Hotarubi No Mori E
entry.content:
One of my favorite manga short stories, Hotarubi no Mori e by Yuki Midorikawa, was just made into an anime film! I cried after reading the story, and I cried after the animated film ended too. One would think that already knowing the ending would have removed the emotion from the film, but I guess not.

tears everywhere, seriously (source)

[spoilers ahead]

I haven't read much manga recently, but what stories I've read from Midorikawa still remain glowing in my memory. She always takes a single, strange premise -- a criminal investigator that can make people do as he says, a boy who inherits his grandmother's "book of names" of spirits -- and uses story to cast light into the unique possibilities given by that premise, really stretches and shines it out to its full potential.

Hotarubi no Mori e in particular is my favorite of hers, because it's so wonderfully concise, whole, and focused. A human and a spirit meet and become friends, despite a peculiar limitation: if the spirit ever encounters human touch, he will vanish from the world.

Significant events and points of growth in the characters' relationship revolve around the problem of contact. When the two first meet, they carry a stick between them to hold hands. One day, when the human falls from a tree, the spirit races to catch her -- before pulling back at the last moment to let her crash. Afterward, she weeps -- "Never touch me, ever!" -- and those different facets of the premise sparkle to light. You understand it without the burden of over-narration; you understand simply, just as it happens. He can't protect her. He can't even comfort her. You watch her sob and sob and the spirit sits close by, face hidden by his mask.

When people say that they just had to keep reading/watching/consuming because they want to see what will happen -- this story really dazed me with that desperation. The conflict seems so impossible -- you know what's going to happen, what must happen -- but does it? Is there any other way that this story could end?

Do yourself a favor and find out! :)
